{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3502192,"name":"Ian Owens","username":"IanRaiders","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T21:22:00.491Z","cooked":"

We used PheonixTuner to generate our swerve code. AdvantageScope is also set up. When we drive forward, the robot goes forward. Backwards, it goes back. Left and right work as well. However, when we try to turn our robot with the right joystick, the front and the back motors appear to be swapped. I cannot be sure that swapping them would work due to the motions required to drive and spin at the same time, but I can be sure that this is what the pattern looks like. AdvantageScope seems to think that our robot is turning correctly. I can tell you with certainty that the robot is not turning correctly. Below is a diagram of what our robot does when we try rotating left.

swerveproblem1920×2560 604 KB

R is simply an indicator of which side is the right side, for our dyslexic folk

We zeroed our encoders properly, and we have ensured they were zeroed correctly by doing it again and again. I tried swapping front and back motors in the code multiple ways, though it did not work and instead made the robot drive even more chaotically - alternatively, I did not swap them correctly and cannot figure out the proper way. I tried rotating our Pigeon 2.0 as it was on wrong, though it did not solve our issue - it did not do anything, actually. We have ensured that everything is updated to the latest version, though no change was found. We saw something in swervekinematics that might solve our issue, though those posts did not seem to help - again, we could be doing it wrong.

Anything that might help would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advanced!

Try running each of the 8 motors individually, and see if anything is amiss. For example, command only the front left drive motor to run, and confirm that’s the motor that actually runs.
